protocol_name: Analysis and characterization of the carbohydrate fraction of Aiptasia and coral tissue using targeted GC-MS
protocol_name_html: Analysis and characterization of the carbohydrate fraction of Aiptasia and coral tissue using targeted GC-MS
description:
The description and identification of metabolites using Gas Chromatography - Mass Spectrometry (GC-MS) is a powerful tool to study the cnidarian-dinoflagellate symbiosis. The applications range from first descriptions of metabolite profiles to the identification of specific metabolic responses (e.g. biomarkers) of the cnidarian metaorganism (‘holobiont’), including its associated symbionts, under stress.

 

The following step-by-step protocol is optimized to characterize the carbohydrate fraction from Aiptasia anemones or coral fragments, as well as their algal symbionts, using a targeted GC-MS approach. The protocol was previously used in Ochsenkühn et al. (2017) where it identified the following carbohydrates (floridoside, inositol, mannitol, glucose, glycerol, galactose, ribose and fructose) as well as some amino acids (glycine, alanine, valine and proline).

 

In addition to the step-by-step protocol for sample preparation and derivatization, we provide detailed settings for the Agilent GC-MS system (GC (Agilent 7890A) and MS (Agilent 5975C)) in a separate document.
warning:
The derivatization reaction steps have to be done in a fume hood as both reagants (MOX and MSTFA) are volatile and toxic (corrosive).

Wear goggles and a double layer of gloves and remove directly in case of any spill.
protocol_affiliation: King Abdullah University of Science and Technology,NYUAD
manuscript_citation: Ochsenkühn, M. A., Röthig, T., D’Angelo, C., Wiedenmann, J. and Voolstra, C. R. (2017). The role of floridoside in osmoadaptation of coral-associated algal endosymbionts to high-salinity conditions. Sci. Adv. 3, e1602047.
keywords: GC-MS, Symbiosis, Salinity, Carbohydrates, Metabolomics, coral, aiptasia, sugars, mass-spectrometry

authors_list.name: Hagen Gegner
authors_list.affiliation: King Abdullah University of Science and Technology

authors_list.name: Christian Voolstra
authors_list.affiliation: King Abdullah University of Science and Technology

guidelines: It is crucial that all steps, until the derivatization, are performed on ice to minimize degradation of metabolites. Normalization is essential for GC-MS data, as such, two options (dry-weight and total protein content) are included in this protocol.
status_info: We use this protocol in our group and it is working

components.data: Sample collection
components.name: Section

components.data:
At the end of your experiment:

 

  • Rinse anemones or coral fragments with ddH2O to reduce the salt load
  • Transfer anemones to cryotubes or in the case of coral fragments to a falcon tube or wrap in aluminum foil and snap freeze in liquid nitrogen
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
At the end of your experiment:

 

  • Rinse anemones or coral fragments with ddH2O to reduce the salt load
  • Transfer anemones to cryotubes or in the case of coral fragments to a falcon tube or wrap in aluminum foil and snap freeze in liquid nitrogen

components.data: Sample collection
components.name: Section

components.data:
Store at -80 °C or continue with the protocol

 

Decide on the normalization method by following the step-case below:

  • to protein content, directly follow the rest of the protocol
  • to dry-weight, follow the steps and then go back to step-case 'normalization to protein content' to continue with the rest of the protocol
components.name: Description

components.data: Sample preparation (Protein content normalization)
components.name: Section

components.data:
Transfer samples

  • For Aiptasia simply add 3ml ddH2O and transfer to a Falcon tube
  • For corals
    • use an airbrush to remove the tissue (add up to 15ml ddH2O)
      • or mortal and pestel cooled with liquid nitrogen to grind everything to powder and add up to 15ml ddH2O
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Transfer samples

  • For Aiptasia simply add 3ml ddH2O and transfer to a Falcon tube
  • For corals
    • use an airbrush to remove the tissue (add up to 15ml ddH2O)
      • or mortal and pestel cooled with liquid nitrogen to grind everything to powder and add up to 15ml ddH2O

components.data: Sample preparation
components.name: Section

components.data:
Thaw samples on ice and add ddH2O

  • For Aiptasia add 1ml ddH2O
  • For corals use an airbrush to remove the tissue or crush/pulverize fragments in liquide nitrogen (if not done already)
    • add up to 15ml ddH2O (the more you use the longer it takes in the next steps)
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Thaw samples on ice and add ddH2O

  • For Aiptasia add 1ml ddH2O
  • For corals use an airbrush to remove the tissue or crush/pulverize fragments in liquide nitrogen (if not done already)
    • add up to 15ml ddH2O (the more you use the longer it takes in the next steps)

components.data: Sample preparation
components.name: Section

components.data: Sonicate using a tip ultrasonicator (e.g. Branson digital sonifier) on ice at 7 watts for 2min until everything is dissolved.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Sonicate using a tip ultrasonicator (e.g. Branson digital sonifier) on ice at 7 watts for 2min until everything is dissolved.

components.data: Sample preparation
components.name: Section

components.data:
Remove cell debris by centrifuging at 4000g for 20min at 4 °C

 

Keep all samples on ice.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Remove cell debris by centrifuging at 4000g for 20min at 4 °C

 

Keep all samples on ice.

components.data: Sample preparation
components.name: Section

components.data: Move supernatant to Beckman tube (50ml) and add 9 parts of absolute ethanol (cold) to 1 part of sample
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Move supernatant to Beckman tube (50ml) and add 9 parts of absolute ethanol (cold) to 1 part of sample

source_data.body: Balance the tubes for the ultracentrifuge, (+-0.05mg is ok)

components.data: Sample preparation
components.name: Section

components.data: Centrifuge precipitate at 20.000g for 20min at 4 °C in Beckman centrifuge
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Centrifuge precipitate at 20.000g for 20min at 4 °C in Beckman centrifuge
This protocol, developed in 2011 by Angela Poole while in the Weis lab, is a quick prep for protein extraction from Aiptasia adults.
source_data.before_start:
RIPA extraction buffer:

  • 100mM Tris, pH 7.4
  • 100mM NaCl
  • 10mM EDTA, pH 8.0

 

*Bring to desired volume with Nanopure water and just before use, dissolve one cOmplete™, mini, protease inhibitor tablet in 10mL of RIPA Buffer. Be sure to let the tablet dissolve on its own- do not vortex!!

versions.protocol_name_html: Protein extraction from Aiptasia

collections.protocol_name: Getting started with the Aiptasia-Symbiodinium Model System
collections.protocol_name_html: Getting started with the Aiptasia-Symbiodinium Model System

components.data: Prepare anemones by placing in the incubator in artificial seawater (ASW) 3-4 days prior to extraction.  Be sure to change out the (ASW) each day to remove any residual debris.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Prepare anemones by placing in the incubator in artificial seawater (ASW) 3-4 days prior to extraction.  Be sure to change out the (ASW) each day to remove any residual debris.

components.data: Transfer 4-5 large anemones to a small tissue grinder on ice with 0.5-1 mL of chilled extraction buffer. Upon removal from their original container, anemones should be blotted on Kimwipes/weigh paper to remove as much water as possible.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Transfer 4-5 large anemones to a small tissue grinder on ice with 0.5-1 mL of chilled extraction buffer. Upon removal from their original container, anemones should be blotted on Kimwipes/weigh paper to remove as much water as possible.

components.data: Transfer homogenate to a 1.5 mL tube and centrifuge at 14,000xg for 15 minutes at 4°C. This step will pellet the dinoflagellates and cell debris, while the protein will be in the supernatant.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Transfer homogenate to a 1.5 mL tube and centrifuge at 14,000xg for 15 minutes at 4°C. This step will pellet the dinoflagellates and cell debris, while the protein will be in the supernatant.

components.data: Remove the supernatant (be careful not to disturb the white lipid layer!) and place in a new tube.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Remove the supernatant (be careful not to disturb the white lipid layer!) and place in a new tube.

components.data: Determine the concentration of your protein (we used the Bradford assay).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Determine the concentration of your protein (we used the Bradford assay).

components.data: Aliquot your protein into 100 µl volumes and store in the -80°C freezer until further use. Freeze-thaw cycles should be avoided and protein can be kept for a short period in the fridge on ice.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Aliquot your protein into 100 µl volumes and store in the -80°C freezer until further use. Freeze-thaw cycles should be avoided and protein can be kept for a short period in the fridge on ice.

components.data:
Put a kim wipe on the tubes lid, make holes in the lid and cool them down to -80C

(optinal: use Kim wipes and parafilm)

  

After preparation start the lyophilization (e.g. Ultradry lyophilizer)

components.data: Derivatization (preparation)
components.name: Section

components.data:
Preparation of:

  1. GC vials with smaller labels
  2. Heated Thermo Block for GC vials
  3. Concentrator system (max. 40 °C) Coldtrap (on) time 99=continuous (Labconco Centrivap Complete)
  4. Internal standard hydroxyl benzoic acid (ISTD) (1 ug/ul HBA in ddH2O)
  5. Standards for quantification (that depends on the targeted compounds for quantification)
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Preparation of:

  1. GC vials with smaller labels
  2. Heated Thermo Block for GC vials
  3. Concentrator system (max. 40 °C) Coldtrap (on) time 99=continuous (Labconco Centrivap Complete)
  4. Internal standard hydroxyl benzoic acid (ISTD) (1 ug/ul HBA in ddH2O)
  5. Standards for quantification (that depends on the targeted compounds for quantification)

components.data: Derivatization (preparation)
components.name: Section

components.data:
Suspend dried samples in 500μl of ddH2O (its up to you, vials can hold 2ml)

  • vortex vigorously
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Suspend dried samples in 500μl of ddH2O (its up to you, vials can hold 2ml)

  • vortex vigorously

Add 10μl of internal ISTD

 

  • Add the internal Standard to all samples (including your calibration curves of standards for quantification)

components.data: Derivatization (reaction)
components.name: Section

components.data:
Preparation of:

  1. Thermoblock for GC vials
  2. MOX (2% methoxamine HCL in pyridine)
  3. MSTFA (MSTFA, 1% TMCS) (you can also use BSTFA))
  4. Hamilton syringes (100μl)
  5. Plastic syringes
  6. Syringe Filters 
  7. Glass inserts for GC vials
  8. Teflon lids for vials
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Preparation of:

  1. Thermoblock for GC vials
  2. MOX (2% methoxamine HCL in pyridine)
  3. MSTFA (MSTFA, 1% TMCS) (you can also use BSTFA))
  4. Hamilton syringes (100μl)
  5. Plastic syringes
  6. Syringe Filters 
  7. Glass inserts for GC vials
  8. Teflon lids for vials

source_data.body: MOX and MSTFA are volatile and toxic (corrosive) wear goggles, two layers of gloves and work under a fume hood. If a spill occurrs immediately switch gloves.

components.data: Derivatization (reaction)
components.name: Section

components.data: Add 50μl of MOX using a Hamilton syringe to the dried samples and close vials tightly
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Add 50μl of MOX using a Hamilton syringe to the dried samples and close vials tightly

components.data: Derivatization (reaction)
components.name: Section

components.data: put samples in the thermo block for 1h at 75 °C
components.name: Description

source_data.description: put samples in the thermo block for 1h at 75 °C

components.data: Derivatization (reaction)
components.name: Section

components.data:
Remove samples from the thermo block and add 100μl of MSTFA using a Hamilton syringe

 

  • Have a second syringe to break open clumps so everything is accessible for the MSTFA
  • vortex
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Remove samples from the thermo block and add 100μl of MSTFA using a Hamilton syringe

 

  • Have a second syringe to break open clumps so everything is accessible for the MSTFA
  • vortex

components.data: Derivatization (reaction)
components.name: Section

components.data: Close lids tightly and leave again for 1h in the 75 °C thermo block
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Close lids tightly and leave again for 1h in the 75 °C thermo block

components.data: Derivatization (reaction)
components.name: Section

components.data: After 1 h, particles can be removed by syringe filtration through 0.2-micron (13 mm diameter) filters and transfer 120µL to glass inserts placed inside GC vials
components.name: Description

source_data.description: After 1 h, particles can be removed by syringe filtration through 0.2-micron (13 mm diameter) filters and transfer 120µL to glass inserts placed inside GC vials

components.data: Derivatization (reaction)
components.name: Section

components.data: The vials are closed with PTFE septa screw caps or crimp caps and stored at -80 °C until measurement
components.name: Description

source_data.description: The vials are closed with PTFE septa screw caps or crimp caps and stored at -80 °C until measurement

components.data: GC-MS measurement
components.name: Section

components.data:
• On the day of the measurement remove samples from the freezer and let them reach room temperature before measuring.
  • Measure in batches of ca. 10 samples and start with quality control and calibration curves first.
  • Find the settings for the GC-MS attached in an extra document.

 

Good luck.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
• On the day of the measurement remove samples from the freezer and let them reach room temperature before measuring.
  • Measure in batches of ca. 10 samples and start with quality control and calibration curves first.
  • Find the settings for the GC-MS attached in an extra document.

 

Good luck.

  • For Aiptasia add 1ml ddH2O
  • For corals use an airbrush to remove the tissue or crush/pulverize fragments in liquide nitrogen and add up to 15ml ddH2O (the more you use the longer it takes in the next steps)

components.data: Continue with STEP-CASE: Normalization to total protein content and follow the rest of the protocol.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Continue with STEP-CASE: Normalization to total protein content and follow the rest of the protocol.

components.data: Disclaimer
components.name: Section

components.data:
This protocol is a step-by-step guide to extract and analyze the carbohydrate fraction of Aiptasia and coral tissue. We included further notes to separate the algal symbiont fraction from the host fraction. 

 

 

Normalization is essential for GC-MS data, as such two options (dry-weight and total protein content) are included in this protocol. Depending on the method chosen follow the respective 'STEP-CASE' normalization to dry-weight and/or to protein content. 

 

 

To minimize degradation of metabolites, it is advised to work quickly and reduce waiting times. Further, it is crucial that that all steps, until the derivatization, are performed on ice/in the cold. 

 

If you are interested in other protocols related to the model organism Aiptasia:
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
This protocol is a step-by-step guide to extract and analyze the carbohydrate fraction of Aiptasia and coral tissue. We included further notes to separate the algal symbiont fraction from the host fraction. 

 

 

Normalization is essential for GC-MS data, as such two options (dry-weight and total protein content) are included in this protocol. Depending on the method chosen follow the respective 'STEP-CASE' normalization to dry-weight and/or to protein content. 

 

 

To minimize degradation of metabolites, it is advised to work quickly and reduce waiting times. Further, it is crucial that that all steps, until the derivatization, are performed on ice/in the cold. 

 

If you are interested in other protocols related to the model organism Aiptasia:

source_data.protocol_name: Getting started with the Aiptasia-Symbiodinium Model System
source_data.protocol_name_html: Getting started with the Aiptasia-Symbiodinium Model System
source_data.description:
A collection of protocols released as part of the IOS EDGE: Functional-genomics tools for Cnidarian-dinoflagellate symbiosis NSF grant (#1645164).

 

Lead PIs: 

Virginia Weis, Oregon State University

Mauricio Rodriguez-Lanetty, Florida International University

Matthew DeGennaro, Florida International University

Arthur Grossman, Carnegie Institution for Science

John Pringle, Stanford University

 

Protocols for getting started w/ the Aiptasia-Symbiodinium Model System:

-General husbandry and culturing of Aiptasia and Symbiodinium in the laboratory

-DNA, RNA, and protein extraction

-Embedding animals for microscopy

-Genotyping

protocols.protocol_name: General Aiptasia husbandry - Weis Lab
protocols.protocol_name_html: General Aiptasia husbandry - Weis Lab
protocols.description: This protocol describes how Aiptasia stocks are cared for in the Weis lab. The protocol was last updated in 2018. Most students and postdocs tha have been in the Weis lab have contributed to this protocol in some form or another, and they are too numerous to list.

protocols.protocol_name: Cold-shock protocol to bleach Aiptasia
protocols.protocol_name_html: Cold-shock protocol to bleach Aiptasia
protocols.description:
This protocol describes how to use a short-term cold shock to render Aiptasia aposymbiotic.

After the cold shock it includes two possibilities to proceed one faster one with usage of DCMU and a slower and more gentle one with only keeping the animals in the dark.

versions.protocol_name: Cold-shock protocol to bleach Aiptasia
versions.protocol_name_html: Cold-shock protocol to bleach Aiptasia

protocols.protocol_name_html: Menthol protocol to bleach Aiptasia
protocols.description: Method to chemically bleach Aiptasia in small volume dishes.

versions.protocol_name: Menthol protocol to bleach Aiptasia
versions.protocol_name_html: Menthol protocol to bleach Aiptasia

protocols.protocol_name: Culturing Symbiodinium
protocols.protocol_name_html: Culturing Symbiodinium
protocols.description:
we generated five clonal, axenic strains of Symbiodinium. These strains were assigned to clades A (two strains), B, E, and F based on their chloroplast 23S rDNA

sequences. Growth studies in liquid cultures showed that the clade B strain and one of the clade A strains were able to grow photoautotrophically (in light with

no fixed carbon), mixotrophically (in light with fixed carbon), or heterotrophically (in dark with fixed carbon). Here this protocol describes the steps of culturing SSB01 in different types of medium as an example.

versions.protocol_name: Culturing Symbiodinium
versions.protocol_name_html: Culturing Symbiodinium

The method is based on the one described in Xiang et al., 2013.

protocols.protocol_name: Aiptasia spawning and embryo/larvae handling - Weis Lab
protocols.protocol_name_html: Aiptasia spawning and embryo/larvae handling - Weis Lab
protocols.description:
This protocol outlines the steps taken to support sexual reproduction in Aiptasia lab cultures. It also provides steps for handling embryos and larvae, and basic husbandry to keep them alive.

Spawning protocol based on the methods from Grawunder et al. 2015.

protocols.protocol_name_html: Aiptasia spawning and embryo/larvae handling - Pringle Lab
protocols.description:
This protocol seeks to provide all information needed to allow regular spawning of Aiptasia and safe handling of the spawn.

 

It is based on the protocol described in Grawunder et al., 2015.
protocols.authors: Pringle Lab, Santiago Perez, Olivia Barry

versions.protocol_name: Aiptasia spawning and embryo/larvae handling - Pringle Lab
versions.protocol_name_html: Aiptasia spawning and embryo/larvae handling - Pringle Lab

protocols.protocol_name: Embedding living larvae in low-melting agarose for imaging and recovery thereafter
protocols.protocol_name_html: Embedding living larvae in low-melting agarose for imaging and recovery thereafter
protocols.description:
This protocol describes how to use agarose with a low gelling point (27-30°C; often called low-melting agarose) to immobilize Aiptasia larvae for microscopy.

Larvae stay alive and in one place for prolonged periods of several hours but continue to mainly spin around the longitudal axis. After imaging, larvae can easily be retrieved from the agarose and transferred back to artificial sea water.

versions.protocol_name: Embedding living larvae in low-melting agarose for imaging and recovery thereafter
versions.protocol_name_html: Embedding living larvae in low-melting agarose for imaging and recovery thereafter

protocols.protocol_name: Preparing small, live Aiptasia polyps for confocal microscopy
protocols.protocol_name_html: Preparing small, live Aiptasia polyps for confocal microscopy
protocols.description: This protocol, which was developed in 2006 by Santiago Perez while in the Weis lab, provides a way to temporarily immobilize small Aiptasia for live imaging on a confocal microscope. As written, the protocol is used for inverted confocal microscopes, but the glass-bottom dishes can be replaced with a normal glass slide and coverslip for an upright microscope.

versions.protocol_name: Preparing small, live Aiptasia polyps for confocal microscopy
versions.protocol_name_html: Preparing small, live Aiptasia polyps for confocal microscopy

protocols.protocol_name: Symbiodinium / Aiptasia cell pop (crude lysis for PCR template)
protocols.protocol_name_html: Symbiodinium / Aiptasia cell pop (crude lysis for PCR template)
protocols.description: This protocol lyses symbiodinium cells with heat and pellets debris, producing material suitable as crude DNA template for robust PCRs. It is convenient for rapid strain identification from liquid cultures and from Symbiodinium-hosting Aiptasia anemones.

versions.protocol_name: Symbiodinium / Aiptasia cell pop (crude lysis for PCR template)
versions.protocol_name_html: Symbiodinium / Aiptasia cell pop (crude lysis for PCR template)

protocols.protocol_name: 2×CTAB Protocol for Isolation of predominantly Symbiodinium DNA from symbiotic anemones
protocols.protocol_name_html: 2×CTAB Protocol for Isolation of predominantly Symbiodinium DNA from symbiotic anemones
protocols.description:
This protocol is kit-free and can be used to isolate high quality genomic DNA of predominantly Symbiodinium from symbiotic Aiptasia which can be used as e.g. PCR template for genotyping.

 

 It is based on the method described in Coffroth et al., 1992.

versions.protocol_name: 2×CTAB Protocol for Isolation of predominantly Symbiodinium DNA from symbiotic anemones
versions.protocol_name_html: 2×CTAB Protocol for Isolation of predominantly Symbiodinium DNA from symbiotic anemones

protocols.protocol_name: 2×CTAB Protocol for (simultaneous) DNA Isolation from Aiptasia and Symbiodinium
protocols.protocol_name_html: 2×CTAB Protocol for (simultaneous) DNA Isolation from Aiptasia and Symbiodinium
protocols.description:
This protocol is kit-free and can be used to simultanously isolate high quality genomic DNA of Symbiodinium and Aiptasia from symbiotic anemones which can be used e.g. as PCR template for genotyping.

 

 It is based on the method described in Coffroth et al., 1992.

versions.protocol_name: 2×CTAB Protocol for (simultaneous) DNA Isolation from Aiptasia and Symbiodinium
versions.protocol_name_html: 2×CTAB Protocol for (simultaneous) DNA Isolation from Aiptasia and Symbiodinium

protocols.protocol_name: 2×CTAB Protocol for predominantly host DNA isolation from symbiotic Aiptasia
protocols.protocol_name_html: 2×CTAB Protocol for predominantly host DNA isolation from symbiotic Aiptasia
protocols.description:
This protocol is kit-free and can be used to isolate high quality genomic DNA of predominantly Aiptasia from symbiotic anemones which can be used e.g. as PCR template for genotyping.

 

It is based on the method described in Coffroth et al., 1992.

versions.protocol_name: 2×CTAB Protocol for predominantly host DNA isolation from symbiotic Aiptasia
versions.protocol_name_html: 2×CTAB Protocol for predominantly host DNA isolation from symbiotic Aiptasia

protocols.protocol_name: DNA Extraction from Symbiodinium Cultures
protocols.protocol_name_html: DNA Extraction from Symbiodinium Cultures
protocols.description:
Dinoflagellates are unicellular algae that can have photosynthetic or nonphotosynthetic lifestyles. Dinoflagellates in the genus Symbiodinium can enter endosymbiotic associations with corals, providing the metabolic basis for the highly productive and biologically diverse coral-reef ecosystems (Hoegh-Guldberg, 1999), as well as with other cnidarians, including sea anemones and jellyfish, and noncnidarian hosts (Trench, 1993; Lobban et al., 2002; Mordret et al., 2016).

 

Here I describe a protocol for isolating total DNA from Symbiodinium cells.

versions.protocol_name: DNA Extraction from Symbiodinium Cultures
versions.protocol_name_html: DNA Extraction from Symbiodinium Cultures

protocols.protocol_name: Using genomic SCAR markers for genotyping Aiptasia strains
protocols.protocol_name_html: Using genomic SCAR markers for genotyping Aiptasia strains
protocols.description:
This protocol describes (1) how to amplify the genomic markers SCAR3, SCAR4, SCAR5 and SCAR7 (developed by Thornhill et al., 2013) from genomic DNA of Aiptasia, (2) how to use Gibson Assembly® to clone them into a (pCR™II-TOPO®-derived) plasmid and (3) performing colony PCRs to screen for clones to sequence by Sanger sequencing. 

The subcloning is highly recommended since strains might be heterozygous for some or all of the markers. 

 

SCAR: Aiptasia-specific inter-simple sequence repeat (ISSR)-derived sequence characterized amplified region markers.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Legal disclaimer:

GIBSON ASSEMBLY® is a registered trademark of Synthetic Genomics, Inc.

pCR™ and TOPO® are trademarks of Thermo Fisher Scientific and its subsidiaries.

GoTaq® is a registered trademark of Promega Corporation.

versions.protocol_name: Using genomic SCAR markers for genotyping Aiptasia strains
versions.protocol_name_html: Using genomic SCAR markers for genotyping Aiptasia strains

protocols.protocol_name: Symbiodinium-enriched RNA extraction from Aiptasia holobiont
protocols.protocol_name_html: Symbiodinium-enriched RNA extraction from Aiptasia holobiont
protocols.description: This protocol enriches holobiont Exaiptasia pallida tissue for Symbiodinium, removing more than 99% of host tissue while maintaining high RNA integrity (RIN > 7). The symbiont-enriched fraction is subsequently lysed via bead beating and rna isolated using the Qiagen RNeasy Mini kit.

versions.protocol_name: Symbiodinium-enriched RNA extraction from Aiptasia holobiont
versions.protocol_name_html: Symbiodinium-enriched RNA extraction from Aiptasia holobiont

protocols.protocol_name: Symbiodinium cp23S RFLP and sequence analysis
protocols.protocol_name_html: Symbiodinium cp23S RFLP and sequence analysis
protocols.description:
This protocol describes how to perform PCR on extracted Symbiodinium DNA to amplify a fragment of the chloroplast 23S rRNA gene. It is based on the method describes in Pochon et al., 2006. The protocol then explains how to perform an RFLP (restriction fragment length polymorphism) analysis on the PCR products as well as eitherusing them directly for sequence analysis by Sanger sequencing or cloning them into a plasmid back bone to separate genes from mixed Symbiodinium populations and perform the sequence analysis on several clones per original sample.

 

The attached file contains reference sequences of the following Symbiodinium strains: Clade A strains SSA01, SSA02, SSA03; SSB01 (clade B), SSB01del6, SSB01del136, SSE01 (clade E) and A001 (Clade D).

versions.protocol_name: Symbiodinium cp23S RFLP and sequence analysis
versions.protocol_name_html: Symbiodinium cp23S RFLP and sequence analysis

protocols.protocol_name: Protein extraction from Aiptasia
protocols.protocol_name_html: Protein extraction from Aiptasia
protocols.description: This protocol, developed in 2011 by Angela Poole while in the Weis lab, is a quick prep for protein extraction from Aiptasia adults.

versions.protocol_name: Protein extraction from Aiptasia
versions.protocol_name_html: Protein extraction from Aiptasia

source_data.status_info: We use these protocols in the EDGE labs and they are working

components.data: Sample preparation (Protein content normalization)
components.name: Section

components.data: Materials
components.name: Section

components.data:
Chemicals

  • MOX reagent 2% methoxamine HCL in pyridine (e.g. Thermo scientific)
  • MSTFA, 1% TMCS (10x1 ml. (e.g. Sigma 69479-10X1ML))
  • 4-Hydroxybenzoic acid (ISTD = Internal standard)
  • Absolute ethanol ≥99.8% (GC)
  • Standards for quantification ≥99.8% (GC) (This depends on the compounds targeted)
    • We use: Glucose, Mannose, Succrose, Glycine

 

Consumables

  • Falcon tubes (50ml)
  • GC sample vials with Teflon cap (2ml)
  • Glass syringe e.g. Hamilton® syringe, 700 series
  • Syringe filters - 0.2 micron (13 mm diameter)
  • Beckman bottles for Beckmann Coulter centrifuge
  • GC vial glass inlets (0.2ml)
  • Plastic syringes (1ml)
  • Parafilm
  • Kim wipes (or any other tissue)

 

Equipment

  • GC/MS system
    • GC (Agilent 7890A)
    • MS (Agilent 5975C)
    • Autosampler (Agilent 7693)
  • Concentrator system (Labconco Centrivap Complete)
  • Ultracentrifuge (Beckmann Coulter Avanti J-26 XP)
  • FreezeDryer (Ultradry)
  • Ultrasonicator (Branson digital sonifier)
  • Homogenizer (MicroDisTec MDT 125) (if needed)
  • Centrifuge (Eppendorf 5415 R)
  • Thermoblock fitting for GC vials
  • Fume hood
